user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_reset:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_reset (struct DigestAlgorithm *da)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
#else  /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#endif /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_MD5_reset (&da->ctx.md5_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
#else  /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#endif /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_SHA256_reset (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
  {
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
    MHD_SHA512_256_init (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  {
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif
    mhd_assert (0); /* May not happen, bad algorithm */
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The function parameter is 'struct DigestAlgorithm *da'. There are no assignments to the pointer variable itself (no occurrences like 'da = ...' or modifying da directly). The code only accesses/modifies the object pointed to (e.g. da->ready_for_hashing = true/false and calls that pass &da->ctx.* to reset/init functions). Per Rule 17.8 this is allowed: the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself must not be modified. The mhd_assert usages only evaluate members and do not assign to the parameter. Conditional compilation branches (#ifdef) also only perform member assignments or call reset/init functions on members, so none of them violates the rule. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
